original_text: This positive reinforcement not only makes the process more enjoyable but also fosters a sense of community among users.1The psychological benefits of micro-savings and the resulting feeling of progress can also be leveraged.7 Micro-savings caters to individuals who may have limited income to spare, allowing them to save even the smallest amounts of money over time.8 This consistent, albeit small, saving can lead to a tangible sense of accomplishment and progress towards achieving financial security.9 A common feature in micro-savings apps is the "roundup," which automatically deposits the spare change from everyday purchases into a savings account.9The concept of "soft commitments" offers another valuable approach to goal setting within a gentler budgeting framework.11 Soft commitments are non-binding agreements that have been shown to enhance motivation and improve the completion rate of complex tasks, such as adhering to financial goals.12 Unlike "hard commitments" that may involve financial penalties, soft commitments primarily rely on the psychological cost of not adhering to one's self-imposed intentions.15The use of "implementation intentions" can also be instrumental in fostering positive financial habits.16 Implementation intentions involve creating specific "if-then" rules that pre-plan how an individual will respond in particular financial situations, thereby automating positive behaviors.16

original_text: For example, a user might set an implementation intention such as, "If it is Friday afternoon, then I will review my spending for the week".16Finally, understanding the principles of loss aversion and framing can be applied to provide gentle course correction in spending habits.18 Loss aversion describes the psychological tendency for individuals to feel the pain of a loss more acutely than the pleasure of an equivalent gain.18 This principle can be leveraged by framing alerts for overspending as opportunities to make adjustments and get back on track, rather than as indicators of failure.

original_text: Qapital offers users the ability to establish personalized rules that trigger the transfer of small amounts of money to savings based on their spending habits.26 Similarly, Digit automatically identifies small amounts of money that can be moved from a user's checking account to a savings account based on their spending patterns and income.4The shift towards "soft intentions" can be facilitated by designing flexible goal-setting mechanisms that allow for easy adjustments and focus on overarching aspirations rather than rigid, anxiety-inducing targets.27 For instance, PocketGuard allows users to define specific and achievable financial goals within their budget framework using the SMART criteria (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound) and provides tools to monitor progress towards these goals.31 The broader concept of "soft savings" acknowledges the importance of present-day spending while still maintaining a focus on future financial security.27Finally, the "gentle tap on the shoulder" for overspending can be achieved by developing non-alarming and encouraging alerts that prioritize guidance and support over shame or reprimand.1 These alerts could be customized based on individual spending habits and preferences to feel less intrusive.1 Instead of using jarring visual cues like "red flags," the system could employ more subtle and supportive language, such as "gentle reminders" or suggestions for "course correction" to help users adjust their spending without feeling criticized.
